liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas lost $3 billion more than it made under Alan Joyce
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi, Sue Lannin here jumping in for a guest post. I've been crunching Qantas' bottom line, and it has made huge losses during the 15 years of outgoing chief executive Alan Joyce's tenure. Airlines are a tough industry, with wars, pandemics, natural disasters, and financial crises the main factors that drive away passengers. Over the past 15 years, Qantas has been hit by COVID-19, which shut down the global travel industry, high fuel costs, fleet writedowns, and the global financial crisis, when toxic investments in the US almost brought down the world's financial system. Qantas net profit verses losses breakdown From 2008 to 2022, Qantas lost $2.9 billion, which wiped out the profits it made during the period. The rebound from COVID-19 has seen the airline return to profit for 2023, making a record $1 billion for the half year. Annual net losses 2022: $860 million loss 2021: $1.7 billion loss 2020: $1.9 billion loss 2014: $2.83 billion loss 2012: $$245 million loss 2008 - 2022 Total annual net loss: $7.6 billion Annual net profits 2019: $891 million profit 2018: $980 million profit 2017: $852 million profit 2016: $1.029 billion profit 2015: $560 million profit 2013: $5 million profit 2011:$249 million profit 2010: $112 million profit 2009: $117 million profit 2008: $969 million profit 2008 - 2022 Total annual net profit $4.7 billion

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Unions warn new Qantas CEO will have 'uphill' road ahead to rebuild
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory. â€œTodayâ€™s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said. â€œOver a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was. "Joyceâ€™s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends. "Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia." Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Vanessa Hudson on succeeding Alan Joyce as Qantas CEO
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Incoming Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she's "incredibly excited" to succeed Alan Joyce in the role, and she's looking forward to working with aviation unions to build constructive relationships.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: New CEO chosen from a 'very wide range' of potential candidates
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The final question of the media conference was directed to Qantas chair Richard Goyder about the potential candidates who were in the running to replace Alan Joyce. After a global search, Mr Goyder said there were close to 40 potential candidates, and "most of them were male". "The two outstanding candidates were the two internal female candidates, and the board went through the right process. "We spent time with Vanessa [Hudson] and Olivia [Wirth] and while I say it's never easy, the board firmly feels that [Vanessa] is the right person to take Qantas forward. "Not just because of her background and what she's achieved to date but we think she's got, in aviation terms, a lot of runway to build and grow her career, and in the process make sure that Qantas is bigger, better and stronger in the years ahead."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: New Qantas boss focused on improving customer experience
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: One major hurdle Ms Hudson will face as new CEO of Qantas will be improving customer relations and experiences, which have slipped in recent years in the wake of the COVID pandemic. She was asked about how she would restore the national carrier's reputation, to which she said improving customer experience will be at the forefront. "We are very up-front in terms of  recognising that the customer  experience was not where we wanted it to be, we have invested in an  enormous amount of money," she said. "This year again the performance is back where we were pre-COVID and our focus  going forward is going to continue to improve." "We have an enormous amount of initiatives that are in the  pipeline including investment in new lounges but most notably it we have a new pipeline of reviewing our  fleet which will deliver the next  step change in customer experience including Project Sunrise but it  will also deliver growth."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Leaving Qantas 'a bittersweet moment for me', Joyce says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Alan Joyce has used the first part of his speech to commend Qantas for making history in appointing Vanessa Hudson as his replacement. "I am  pleased that the 103 years of what this is history it has been at 12  CEOs," he said. "This is the first female CEO and that length of time and that is a credit to the merit and the  capability of the strong women that we have in the management team. "There's not many female CEOs in the worldwide aviation industry and as a credit to this country that gay man was appointed 15 years ago to be CEO of the company and now we have the first female accredited to the  board." Mr Joyce still has six months left in the role before he leaves in November, and says he still has plenty of work ahead of him. "I have a lot of things to do but this is certainly, going to be a bittersweet moment for me because  I'm passionate about this company, I am passionate about Qantas, it has been my life for so long but the  timing is right. "As Richard said, if it had not been for COVID I would have retired a few years ago. "I have agreed to stay if this length of  time to help the company get through that terrible crisis and make sure that it is strong coming out and I believe that we are really strong  now and settled well for the future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Incoming CEO pays tribute to Joyce's time in the role
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's some of what incoming Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has had to say about her history-making appointment: "I know that I would not be here if it was not for Alan, your leadership, the leadership team that I have  worked with over the last couple of years but also the broader people  that I have worked with across  Qantas, I know that they bring out the best in me and for them I would not be here today," she said. "It's such an honour to be stepping into this role in  November and I'm incredibly excited about not just the opportunity but about the future because there is so much to look forward to over the  coming years. "I am so passionate  about Qantas, I have worked for  Qantas for 28 years and the  excitement of the first day that I felt walking into Qantas, I feel  still today."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Qantas chair: Joyce has led us through turbulent times
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder has started the press conference thanking outgoing CEO Alan Joyce for his service. "There will be plenty of time to talk about Alan's achievement as the year and fold but I do want to recall the boards and my own  appreciation for everything Alan has done to date including leading the airline through a period of time  which was really existential in  terms of Qantas's outlook," Goyder said. "The  board and shareholders back in 2020 asked him to stay on through the  pandemic which he agreed to do."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Alan Joyce and new Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson to speak
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Outgoing Qantas CEO Alan Joyce is about to speak after the airline announced its chief financial officer, Vanessa Hudson would succeed him in the role. We'll also hear from the incoming CEO, Ms Hudson herself, who has made history as the first female CEO of Qantas in its 103-year history. You can watch the full press conference below, which is due to start shortly:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Woolworths records 8pc growth in sales as supply chains recover
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Woolworths Group has recorded an 8% growth in its sales in the third quarter compared to the same time last year, with growth across all of its businesses â€” including a near 8% increase in food sales. CEO Brad Banducci said supply chains are slowly recovering, but notes that customers are becoming increasingly wary about the impact that ongoing inflation is having on household budgets. "In general, customer spending is stable. However, v alue-conscious customers are becoming more thoughtful about their discretionary spend, trading into more affordable options such as our own brands and looking for additional ways to save in store or through our Digital, Rewards and eCommerce platforms," Mr Banducci said. The food sales arm of the business saw a 7.6% increase to $12.3 billion in the third quarter, with food retail sales growing by 7.4%.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Housing affordability worsens as property prices rise for second straight month
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: House prices have risen for the second month in a row, with analysts suggesting the market may have bottomed. Rents are also rising, which is putting extra pressure on the federal government to do something about the affordability crisis. It says it's not considering scrapping tax concessions, like negative gearing for investors, but will offer tax breaks to developers in next week's budget to build more rental properties. You can watch the full story from my colleague, business reporter Nassim Khadem, below ðŸ‘‡

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Incoming Qantas CEO says it's an 'honour' to lead national carrier
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us â€” our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'It's a logical time for me to step down', Joyce says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Outgoing Qantas boss Alan Joyce was asked to stay on as the airline's CEO as it recovered from the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, but Mr Joyce says now is the right time to step aside. "Now that weâ€™re on the other side of that crisis itâ€™s a logical time for me to step down," he said. "Thereâ€™s still a  lot I want to deliver in the next six months and at the top of that list is ensuring a smooth handover to  Vanessa, who Iâ€™m sure will excel in the role." Qantas chair Richard Goyder paid tribute to Mr Joyce for his years at the helm of the national carrier. â€œMuch of the credit for the bright future in front of Qantas goes to Alan," Mr Goyder said. "Heâ€™s faced more than his fair share  of challenges as CEO and heâ€™s managed them exceptionally well â€“ from the GFC, to record oil prices, to  intense competitive pressures and the COVID crisis. "The company was restructured to deal with a number of external shocks and Alan led it to a several record  profits. "Alan has done a superb job of leading a team that is absolutely committed to the national carrierâ€™s long-term success and itâ€™s from that team that his successor has been chosen."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BREAKING: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce to step down in November, replaced by CFO Vanessa Hudson
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could the government see a budget surplus by the end of the year?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's certainly the optimistic forecasts by some, including independent economist Chris Richardson. He believes there's a chance of seeing a "wafer thin" surplus over the year to March, which would put treasurer Jim Chalmers in sight of the first budget surplus Australia has seen in 15 years. What's behind this potential surplus? Commodity prices, in particular booming iron ore and thermal coal prices. But that's not to say deficits will be a thing of the past â€” as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains in the clip below ðŸ‘‡

liveBlogUpdate.headline: House prices haven't just stabilised â€” they've turned the corner
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CoreLogic data released yesterday show house prices have rebounded from their downturn, rising for a second consecutive month. Every capital city, with the exception of Darwin, saw a rise in real estate prices, led by Sydney. Regional areas also saw some minor gains. But against all logic and what previous experience has shown us, house prices appear to have not just stabilised but turned a corner. You can read more of this analysis by business editor Ian Verrender below ðŸ‘‡

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog â€” and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call â€” in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on â€” pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.

"I have agreed to stay if this length of  time to help the company get through that terrible crisis and make sure that it is strong coming out and I believe that we are really strong  now and settled well for the future."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woolworths Group has recorded an 8% growth in its sales in the third quarter compared to the same time last year, with growth across all of its businesses â€” including a near 8% increase in food sales. CEO Brad Banducci said supply chains are slowly recovering, but notes that customers are becoming increasingly wary about the impact that ongoing inflation is having on household budgets. "In general, customer spending is stable. However, v alue-conscious customers are becoming more thoughtful about their discretionary spend, trading into more affordable options such as our own brands and looking for additional ways to save in store or through our Digital, Rewards and eCommerce platforms," Mr Banducci said. The food sales arm of the business saw a 7.6% increase to $12.3 billion in the third quarter, with food retail sales growing by 7.4%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Newly-appointed Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson says she is honoured to be appointed the company's 13th CEO in its 103-year history. Ms Hudson is the airline's first female CEO and has a long history with the company. She was part of the committee that shaped Qantas's strategy, helped it navigate the impacts of COVID, and led its fleet selection process. "It's an absolute honour to be asked to lead the national carrier. This is an exceptional  company full of incredibly talented people and it's very well positioned for the future," she said. "My focus will be  delivering for those we rely on and who rely on us â€” our customers, our employees, our shareholders and  the communities we serve." Qantas will announce its new CFO to replace Ms Hudson "in the months ahead". We'll hear more from outgoing CEO Alan Joyce and Ms Hudson later this morning.

"Now that weâ€™re on the other side of that crisis itâ€™s a logical time for me to step down," he said. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has confirmed this morning that current CEO Alan Joyce will retire in November this year and will be replaced by the group's chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson. Ms Hudson has worked across a number of positions with Qantas over the past 28 years, including chief customer officer and senior vice-president for the Americas and New Zealand. Qantas chairman Richard Goyder said the appointment came after a rigorous selection process for Mr Joyce's replacement. "Vanessa has a deep understanding of this business after almost three decades in a range of roles both onshore and offshore, across commercial, customer and finance," he said. Mr Joyce has been at the helm of Qantas for 15 years, and will step down in November after extending his tenure at the board's request to help the airline's COVID recovery.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Tuesday May 2 and you've found yourself on the ABC's markets and business blog â€” and what a day we have in front of us. Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first: it's rates day. The RBA is meeting today to decide what to do with the cash rate, after leaving rates on hold at 3.6% in April. But we know that was a lineball call â€” in the meeting minutes published a couple of weeks later, the RBA board had considered another rise of 0.25 percentage points. So what could today's decision look like? Major banks and investors are widely predicting the RBA will leave the cash rate unchanged at 3.6%, with data last week showing inflation is slowly coming down. I'll bring you the latest on that decision when it happens at 2:30pm AEST, and all the reaction that follows. On the markets front, the Australian share market is looking to open lower this morning after ASX futures were down -0.1% to 7,336 points as of 7:30am. It follows a mixed performance on Wall Street overnight, with US financial markets largely dominated by the news that regulators had seized First Republic, before selling its assets to JPMorgan Chase to fight off another global banking crisis. First Republic is the third US bank to collapse in just two months, after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank folded earlier this year. All in all, there's a bit on â€” pour yourself a coffee and let's see where the day takes us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to slip as Reserve Bank rates decision looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi, Sue Lannin here jumping in for a guest post. I've been crunching Qantas' bottom line, and it has made huge losses during the 15 years of outgoing chief executive Alan Joyce's tenure. Airlines are a tough industry, with wars, pandemics, natural disasters, and financial crises the main factors that drive away passengers. Over the past 15 years, Qantas has been hit by COVID-19, which shut down the global travel industry, high fuel costs, fleet writedowns, and the global financial crisis, when toxic investments in the US almost brought down the world's financial system. Qantas net profit verses losses breakdown From 2008 to 2022, Qantas lost $2.9 billion, which wiped out the profits it made during the period. The rebound from COVID-19 has seen the airline return to profit for 2023, making a record $1 billion for the half year. Annual net losses 2022: $860 million loss 2021: $1.7 billion loss 2020: $1.9 billion loss 2014: $2.83 billion loss 2012: $$245 million loss 2008 - 2022 Total annual net loss: $7.6 billion Annual net profits 2019: $891 million profit 2018: $980 million profit 2017: $852 million profit 2016: $1.029 billion profit 2015: $560 million profit 2013: $5 million profit 2011:$249 million profit 2010: $112 million profit 2009: $117 million profit 2008: $969 million profit 2008 - 2022 Total annual net profit $4.7 billion

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier. TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory. â€œTodayâ€™s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said. â€œOver a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was. "Joyceâ€™s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends. "Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia." Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions warn new Qantas CEO will have 'uphill' road ahead to rebuild

children.content: The Transport Workers Union has issued a statement about Vanessa Hudson's appointment to Qantas's top job, warning she will face an "uphill" road to rebuild the national carrier.

TWU national secretary Michael Kaine says standards have been "shattered" over the 15 years Alan Joyce has been in the role, and says Ms Hudson has a "golden opportunity" to correct the airline's trajectory.

â€œTodayâ€™s announcement is by no means a sign of relief to aviation workers, especially the 1,700 illegally sacked ground workers still suffering on the sidelines. But this is a golden opportunity for a reset at Qantas," he said.
â€œOver a decade Alan Joyce has systematically splintered his workforce and driven down standards to the point where Qantas is a shadow of what it once was.
"Joyceâ€™s position became untenable because Qantas was treated as a corporate vessel for excessive executive bonuses and shareholder dividends.
"Vanessa Hudson must be courageous enough to steer Qantas back to its core purpose: high-quality service for passengers and investment in the hard-working people who built the spirit of Australia."

Mr Kaine says the union's door is open for Ms Hudson to meet with worker representatives, and comes as the new Qantas boss told a media conference she was looking forward to developing a "constructive relationship" with unions.

So many amazing looks but my faves are definitely Margot Robbie, Dua Lipa, and Naomi Campbell - R Completely agree with you, I love all three of these ladies!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The biggest tribute to Karl Lagerfeld yet
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And when I say biggest, I mean it! Here's Jeremy Pope posing with a huge train, complete with Karl and his iconic sunglasses.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aubrey Plaza and Stella McCartney arrive at the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Plaza is actually wearing one of McCartney's designs tonight. Speaking to reporters a little earlier on the red carpet, she weighed in on Jared Leto coming as Karl cat Choupette. Plaza: I know about the cat â€¦ he took that head off way too soon.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Which looks have been your favourites so far?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We've seen plenty of looks already and I'm keen to know your thoughts! Any favourites? Let us know in the comments! Personally, I feel like there's been a lot less drama this year as the theme lends itself to more timeless concepts.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Paris Hilton is en route
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here she is leaving The Mark Hotel earlier.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: I take back what I said about Janelle Monae's look..
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In a pretty seamless carpet reveal, the dress has transformed and the jackets are gone.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The many looks of Cardi B
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: So Cardi B wore this incredible pink look when she left The Mark Hotel earlier. But I was wondering why it took her so long to appear at the actual Met Gala â€¦ And as it turns out, she had an outfit change and walked the famous steps of the Met in this black outfit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Janelle Monae is embracing the 'Queenslanders when it gets below 20 degrees' aesthetic
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Now that's a look I can get behind.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: EGOT winner Viola Davis gives us a much-needed boost of colour
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: This pink is ravishing.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Florence Pugh arrives with a new look and a headpiece to match
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The actress has revealed she's shaved her head for an upcoming film, telling reporters on the red carpet there was "no better way to release it to the world than at The Met". Florence: I've been keeping it under wraps for about three weeks now â€¦ [I'm] very happy to have it here with this look.

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's Bella Ramsey!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jenna Ortega
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: HUGE Wednesday vibes.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Serena Williams arrives with her husband â€¦ and their new plus one ðŸ¥°
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Serena Williams has arrived at the Met Gala in a black and white piece by Gucci, and has announced that she and her husband Alexis Ohanian are expecting their second child together. "Was so excited when Anna Wintour invited the 3 of us to the Met Gala," she wrote on Instagram.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Kendall Jenner rounding out the Kardashian camp
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Kendall Jenner being invited was a pretty safe bet considering she was on the cover of Vogue recently which honoured Karl Lagerfeld.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Kim Kardashian arrives at the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And the rumours about a Kardashian ban have well and truly been put to rest.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Climate activists protest as celebrities leave The Mark Hotel
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Why protest outside The Mark Hotel? Well, it's an exclusive hotel where many celebrities get ready for the Met Gala, so heaps of photgraphers and fans wait around hoping to catch a glimpse. Plus, there's way too much security at the actual Met Gala for the activists to get close to the inside.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Brittney Griner attends Met Gala after release from Russian prison last year
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The WNBA star was released in a high-level prisoner exchange for Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout in December. Griner was detained in February last year after arriving in Russia with vape cartridges filled with "hashish oil", and was later found guilty of drug possession and smuggling. She's among a number of athletes attending tonight's invite-only event, and is there with her wife, Cherelle Griner.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Kylie Jenner has arrived
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Our first Jenner sighting of the night. I actually love this as it's one of the only bold colours on the carpet.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Lily Collins pays tribute to Karl Lagerfeld
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ... by wearing a train with his name written on it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: I do my hair toss, check my nails â€¦
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Lizzo has arrived at fashion's biggest night and she's back with the beads. She brought a flute to last year's event and serenaded people on the steps of the Met Gala, so we'll see if we get to hear it again this time around.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Maya Hawke
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: She looks snug as a bug in a rug.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Kendall Roy spotted at the Met
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The juice is loose, baby! He is taking this so seriously. I love it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Lil Nas X
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Finally something weird! Took us a bit too long to get here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Anne Hathaway
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: My GOODNESS. She is mother, as the youths of today would say.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Vanessa Hudgens
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Baby V! I like it.

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I'm chasing down HD pictures like my life depends on it. I heard her talking on the red carpet before and she said her daughter (I assume North) is waiting in the car, which is hilarious. Also just spotted Kylie Jenner, but not Kendall (yet).

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Well Jared Leto is definitely dressed as Karl cat Choupette.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Billie Eilish is back in black for this year's Karl Lagerfeld theme
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Last year, Eilish wore a light green and purple Gucci corseted gown to the Met Gala, where the theme was In America: An Anthology of Fashion.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Tom Ford suits up for the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You'd recognise the name from his self-titled luxury brand, but prior to that he was also the creative director at Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent.

I'll get us some HD pictures to admire shortly. In this video you can hear her saying her hair stylist used a flower from a Chanel show in the 90s.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Belgian fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg arrives for fashion's biggest night
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: She's here with her husband, Barry Diller, the founder of Fox Broadcasting Company. Von Furstenberg is known for her wrap dress, which you can see on display tonight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ashley Graham

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Sydney Sweeney
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The It Girl of the moment is here. Is she dating her Anyone But You co-star Glen Powell? Nobody knows, but one thing is for sure: I freaking love this look. The bow in the hair! The bow around the knees! Ugh.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Margot Robbie
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As I mentioned before, Margot is wearing a dress design originally worn by Cindy Crawford back in 1993.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The trim, the chain, the tailoring
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Ben Platt has arrived at the Met Gala straight from his audition to become the newest member of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band. I'm a fan, it's a nice change from the traditional suit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Amanda Seyfried
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I actually love this a lot, maybe because I'm digging the hair so much.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Anok Yai is another favourite
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I have been wishing and waiting for a stunning full length photo of this look and now I can finally share it. Another favourite of mine from tonight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Stop everything! Robert Pattinson is here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I am OBSESSED with this man. Borderline unhinged right now seeing him at the Met Gala. And his girlfriend Suki Waterhouse, singer and star of Daisy Jones and the Six, looks absolutely stunning.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Hugh Jackman and Deborra-Lee Furness have arrived at the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And they're continuing the trend away from white. It's a good call, black makes it way harder to tell when you've spilled tomato sauce on your outfit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Margot Robbie was the last Chanel ambassador Karl Lagerfeld picked
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Another Aussie alert! Margot Robbie is here and she's looking gorgeous. I will get us pics ASAP! She's wearing the same dress worn by Cindy Crawford in 1993. "They remade it for me and it's a Karl design so I feel really great in it actually," she said on the red carpet. "Obviously the Met is also an exciting night but I had the great privilege of getting to know Karl to an extent. I was the last Chanel ambassador that he picked, so it's an honour. I'm thrilled they're honouring him tonight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: It's noice, it's different, it's unusual
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: English model and singer-songwriter Karen Elson has arrived at the Met Gala. Her runway modelling credits include Gucci, Marc Jacobs, Jean-Chanel, Dolce & Gabbana and Versace, among others.

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: One of my favourites from tonight! Michaela wears a Schiaparelli gown adorned with 130,000 crystals.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Catherine Martin and Baz Luhrmann
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: More Aussies! They look so good together.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's why Nicole Kidman's dress might look familiar
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's the same dress she wore in her 2004 Chanel No. 5 commercial she did with Australian director Baz Luhrmann. "I think my deep, deep love of Karl came from this time together," Nicole said on the Met Gala red carpet. "So to be able to honour him and wear this dress for Chanel, I suppose the way these couture gowns last. If you take care of them and love them, they are timeless."

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You gotta keep the drama under wraps!

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I am SUCH a fan of Emma Chamberlain and I'm loving this blue fit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How much is a Met Gala ticket?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's not really about how much a ticket costs, because even celebrities can't just buy a ticket. The Met Gala is so exclusive that you have to be invited. Generally companies buy tables. A fashion label would then host its desired celebrities. This year, the cost has gone up, as it does every few years because even the Met isn't immune to inflation: It's now $50,000 for an individual ticket, and tables start at $300,000 .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dua Lipa has arrived!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: She's the first Met Gala co-chair I've spotted tonight. Fans have already clocked she's wearing Chanel Fall/Winter 1992 couture.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Who are this year's Met Gala co-chairs and what do they actually do?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: This year's five hosts are drawn from television, film, sports and music, including: Emmy-winning writer, actor and producer Michaela Coel Oscar-winning actor PenÃ©lope Cruz, who has worked with Chanel for more than 20 years recently retired tennis superstar Roger Federer Grammy-winner Dua Lipa Finally, there is Vogue's Anna Wintour (who needs no introduction) running the whole thing as usual. So what do co-chairs actually do ? It's a mix of helping put together the exclusive guest list, working with top chefs to create a specific menu (often aligned with the annual theme) and creating an atmosphere inside the event by selecting specific decor. Plus, there's the traditional hosting element, with co-chairs often taking the stage to perform during the dinner portion of the evening. Phones are strictly off limits, so sadly we never get to see any performances or interior design choices.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Vogue editor Anna Wintour has arrived
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And she's walking the steps of the Met with actor Bill Nighy.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: No, Kim Kardashian hasn't been banned from the Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Since the Met is invite-only, it's only when guests walk the red carpet that we know who made the cut. This year, there will be roughly 400 guests â€” similar to recent years but still lower than pre-pandemic highs of 500-600. As always, Anna Wintour and her team still get to approve every guest. Back in March, gossip tabloid Page Six reported that in Wintour's bid to narrow the guest list, the entire Kardashian clan had been culled. But it looks like the rumours were false, as Kim Kardashian posted these photos with Karl Lagerfeld's cat, Choupette, after spending some time at his office to "get inspiration" ahead of the event. Personally, I predict we'll spot Kendall Jenner (she was featured on Vogue's May cover which paid tribute to Lagerfeld) and I hope and pray Kylie Jenner will debut her relationship with TimothÃ©e Chalamet because that would be INTERESTING.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How to watch the Met Gala red carpet arrivals
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You can watch the whole shebang on the Vogue live stream below, which is due to go live in about 30 minutes.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why the Met's decision to honour Karl Lagerfeld is controversial
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: This year's theme centers on the late designer Karl Lagerfeld, who made an indelible mark on luxury fashion in his long career at Chanel, Fendi and elsewhere. He was also a self-proclaimed "big mouth," publicly sounding off with fatphobia. He spoke against gay men who want to adopt children, migrants, sexual assault survivors, the #MeToo movement and "ugly" people, without apology. "He offended people right and left, making as much of an art out of the cutting aside as the perfectly cut double-face gown," New York Times fashion critic Vanessa Friedman wrote soon after Lagerfeld's death. "He judged," Friedman wrote, "and knew he would be judged himself, but he didn't care. Rather, he embraced it." The choice of Lagerfeld for fashion's biggest night is not without critics. At the time of the announcement, actor and activist Jameela Jamil acknowledge his fashion genius but denounce his "distinctly hateful" remarks, often toward women. "Why is THIS who we celebrate when there are so many AMAZING designers out there who aren't bigoted white men?" Jamil wrote. According to the Met, Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, will look at "the designer's stylistic vocabulary as expressed in aesthetic themes that appear time and again in his fashions from the 1950s to his final collection in 2019." Lagerfeld died in 2019 at the age of 85.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to the 2023 Met Gala
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The time has come! Fashion's biggest night is HERE. I'm Jessica Riga and I am so stoked to be bringing you all the glitz, glamour and celebrity moments from the red carpet of the Met Gala. It's also the first time in two years the Met Gala has returned to its traditional date â€” the first Monday in May (well, Tuesday for us.) I want to hear what you think of what everyone is wearing, so sound off in the comments, smash those reactions and let's get this fashion extravaganza underway!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not really about how much a ticket costs, because even celebrities can't just buy a ticket. The Met Gala is so exclusive that you have to be invited. Generally companies buy tables. A fashion label would then host its desired celebrities. This year, the cost has gone up, as it does every few years because even the Met isn't immune to inflation: It's now $50,000 for an individual ticket, and tables start at $300,000 .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This year's five hosts are drawn from television, film, sports and music, including: Emmy-winning writer, actor and producer Michaela Coel Oscar-winning actor PenÃ©lope Cruz, who has worked with Chanel for more than 20 years recently retired tennis superstar Roger Federer Grammy-winner Dua Lipa Finally, there is Vogue's Anna Wintour (who needs no introduction) running the whole thing as usual. So what do co-chairs actually do ? It's a mix of helping put together the exclusive guest list, working with top chefs to create a specific menu (often aligned with the annual theme) and creating an atmosphere inside the event by selecting specific decor. Plus, there's the traditional hosting element, with co-chairs often taking the stage to perform during the dinner portion of the evening. Phones are strictly off limits, so sadly we never get to see any performances or interior design choices.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Since the Met is invite-only, it's only when guests walk the red carpet that we know who made the cut. This year, there will be roughly 400 guests â€” similar to recent years but still lower than pre-pandemic highs of 500-600. As always, Anna Wintour and her team still get to approve every guest. Back in March, gossip tabloid Page Six reported that in Wintour's bid to narrow the guest list, the entire Kardashian clan had been culled. But it looks like the rumours were false, as Kim Kardashian posted these photos with Karl Lagerfeld's cat, Choupette, after spending some time at his office to "get inspiration" ahead of the event. Personally, I predict we'll spot Kendall Jenner (she was featured on Vogue's May cover which paid tribute to Lagerfeld) and I hope and pray Kylie Jenner will debut her relationship with TimothÃ©e Chalamet because that would be INTERESTING.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This year's theme centers on the late designer Karl Lagerfeld, who made an indelible mark on luxury fashion in his long career at Chanel, Fendi and elsewhere. He was also a self-proclaimed "big mouth," publicly sounding off with fatphobia. He spoke against gay men who want to adopt children, migrants, sexual assault survivors, the #MeToo movement and "ugly" people, without apology. "He offended people right and left, making as much of an art out of the cutting aside as the perfectly cut double-face gown," New York Times fashion critic Vanessa Friedman wrote soon after Lagerfeld's death. "He judged," Friedman wrote, "and knew he would be judged himself, but he didn't care. Rather, he embraced it." The choice of Lagerfeld for fashion's biggest night is not without critics. At the time of the announcement, actor and activist Jameela Jamil acknowledge his fashion genius but denounce his "distinctly hateful" remarks, often toward women. "Why is THIS who we celebrate when there are so many AMAZING designers out there who aren't bigoted white men?" Jamil wrote. According to the Met, Karl Lagerfeld: A Line of Beauty, will look at "the designer's stylistic vocabulary as expressed in aesthetic themes that appear time and again in his fashions from the 1950s to his final collection in 2019." Lagerfeld died in 2019 at the age of 85.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why the Met's decision to honour Karl Lagerfeld is controversial
